verses.text: He said to me, 'Son of man, stand on your feet, and I will speak with you.'
verses.comment: The address 'son of man' emphasizes Ezekiel's humanity before God, a reminder of humility for those called to serve. This phrase is later applied to Jesus in the Gospels, indicating not just humanity but divinely appointed authority (see Mark 8:38).

verses.text: As he spoke to me, the Spirit entered into me and set me on my feet, and I heard him speaking to me.
verses.comment: The Spirit empowers Ezekiel for his prophetic mission, foreshadowing how the Holy Spirit empowers the apostles (see Acts 2:4). The spiritual life and supernatural equipping of the prophets point toward New Testament believers receiving the Spirit for ministry.

verses.text: He said to me, 'Son of man, I am sending you to the people of Israel, to a nation of rebels who have rebelled against me. They and their fathers have transgressed against me to this very day.'
verses.comment: God sends Ezekiel to Israel despite their constant rebellion. This persistence of God's call, even to the rebellious, echoes the divine patience and the continuing mission to guide the people back to the covenant (cf. Jeremiah 7:25-26).

verses.text: The children are stubborn and hard-hearted. I am sending you to them, and you shall say to them, 'This is what the Lord GOD says.'
verses.comment: Hard-heartedness recalls the Israelites' history of resisting God's word. The phrase 'Thus says the Lord GOD' marks Ezekiel's message as carrying divine authority, paralleling Christ's later use of 'Truly, truly, I say to you.'

verses.text: And whether they listen or refuse—for they are a rebellious house—they will know that a prophet has been among them.
verses.comment: The recognition of a true prophet, despite rejection, prefigures how Jesus was often not received among his own people (Matthew 13:57). Authentic prophetic authority is established by faithfulness, not by popularity.

verses.text: And you, son of man, do not be afraid of them or of their words, though thorns and briers are with you and you sit among scorpions. Do not be afraid of their words or be dismayed by their looks, for they are a rebellious house.
verses.comment: God encourages his prophet with the same words spoken to Jeremiah (Jeremiah 1:8), emphasizing the divine protection and courage given to those commissioned to speak truth, especially when facing persecution.

verses.text: You must speak my words to them, whether they listen or refuse, for they are a rebellious house.
verses.comment: The prophet's duty is to proclaim God's word faithfully, regardless of the people's response. This obedience models how the Church proclaims the gospel to all nations, trusting the results to God.

verses.text: But you, son of man, hear what I say to you. Do not be rebellious like that rebellious house; open your mouth and eat what I am giving you.'
verses.comment: Ezekiel is commanded to partake of the word symbolically by eating, prefiguring receiving God's word interiorly. This anticipates spiritual nourishment themes, as in Revelation 10:9, and highlights the importance of interiorizing the divine message—hinting at sacramental reality.

verses.text: Then I looked, and behold, a hand was stretched out to me, and in it was a scroll.
verses.comment: The scroll represents God's authoritative message. The motif reappears in Revelation 5:1, where only the Lamb can break the seals, linking Ezekiel's prophetic office with the fulfillment of revelation in Christ.

verses.text: He spread it out before me, and it was written on the front and the back. Written on it were words of lamentation, mourning, and woe.
verses.comment: Writing on both sides shows the completeness of God's message—nothing is omitted. The content is judgment and sorrow, preparing God's prophet (and ultimately, God's people) for the seriousness of divine revelation and the call to self-examination prior to restoration. The fullness of both warning and hope finds its ultimate expression in the New Covenant.
